entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: philipp_gortan
entries.text: Philipp has submitted a pull request to Log::Any, to add support for passing structured data. If you use Log::Any, take a look!
entries.title: Add Structured Data to Log::Any

entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: The main news for that week was that Perl 5.26 is now available. Some other stuff went on as well.
entries.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: May 23rd to June 5th

entries.author: yuki_kimoto
entries.text: Kimoto-san has released a new version of his Github replacement, GitPrep, which adds wiki support.
entries.title: GitPrep 2.6

entries.author: andy_lester
entries.text: Perl::Critic, the static code analysis tool for Perl.
entries.title: Perl::Critic 1.128 fixes bugs and works with Perl 5.26

entries.author: jonathan_worthington
entries.text: Jonathan describes some work he did to fix a longstanding I/O bug in MoarVM, funded by Nick Logan.
entries.title: Sorting out synchronous I/O

entries.author: moritz_lenz
entries.text: Moritz summarises the Perl 6 books that are available now, or in development.
entries.title: Perl 6 Books Landscape in June 2017

entries.author: liztormato
entries.text: The weekly roundup of Perl 6 news.
entries.title: 2017.23 Fulfilled TAP

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Gabor is working on a blogging engine in Perl 6, as one of the examples for his book on web application development in Perl 6.
entries.title: Blog engine in Perl 6

entries.author: andy_lester
entries.title: Improve your test logs with simple distro diagnostics

entries.author: david_oswald
entries.text: Information about the Perl Conference, which kicks off next Sunday (18th June) with tutorials from the superband of Anderson, Rolsky, Signes, and Schwartz. If you're going, why not give a lightning talk?
entries.title: The Perl Conference Newsletter

entries.author: paul_zolnierczyk
entries.text: John Anderson and Jay Hannah, who both work for Infinity Interactive, are giving talks at TPC. Infinity are not only a sponsor of the conference, they've developed the conference app for Android and iOS, which you can use to get the most out of your time at TPC. Nice one Infinity!
entries.title: Infinity Interactive's TPC 2017 app

entries.author: andre_walker
entries.text: André has applied for a grant of $3k to have a go at providing a replacement for blogs.perl.org. If you have any thoughts on this, please add comments at the foot of the post.
entries.title: Grant Proposal: Revitalize blogs.perl.org

entries.author: zoffix_znet
entries.text: Zoffix has completed his work on standardisation, test coverage, and documentation of Perl 6 I/O routines, which was supported by a grant. Read about what he did.
entries.title: COMPLETION Report / Perl 6 IO TPF Grant

entries.author: samantha_mcvey
entries.text: A progress report from Samantha on her project to support the robustness of Unicode support in Rakudo. This work is supported by a TPF grant.
entries.title: Grant Report : Robust Perl 6 Unicode Support

entries.author: jim_brandt
entries.text: Mark Prather has volunteered to be the chairman of the TPF community advocacy committee. He has some ideas, but is looking for more fresh blood, if you want to join the committee.
entries.title: The Community Advocacy Committee has a new chair person

entries.author: dave_mitchell
entries.text: Dave's biggest piece of work in May was reworking the sprintf implementation, in the process fixing bugs and making it faster.
entries.title: Dave Mitchell's grant report for May

entries.author: pat_kua
entries.text: A review of O'Reilly's book "Scaling Teams". Pat regularly talks on being a tech leader, and has a lot of experience helping development teams. I'll be adding it to my wishlist.
entries.title: Book Review: Scaling Teams

entries.text: There’s Bad CGI, and there’s Good CGI. Bad CGI involves your web-server standing up new perl processes for incoming requests, where Good CGI makes the films you watch magical. This job – unusually for Perl – involves Good CGI.
entries.title: Lights, Camera ... Perl! - Mid-Level Perl / Ops for the movies (London UK)

entries.text: Not everyone’s like me. Perhaps nobody’s like me. But when it comes to enjoying programming jobs, and particularly when it comes to enjoying Perl programming jobs, there are two things that are needed to make me happy that I suspect resonate with most other career developers.
entries.title: Two Things that Make Developers Happy - Mid-to-Senior Perl Developer in London

entries.text: It’s no secret that I used to run a Perl team myself in Central London, and was competing for talent with the other teams. By far the hardest team to compete with was the one whose technical leader was making sure his team were always using the best tools..
entries.title: Perhaps the most enlightened Perl team in London

header:
The Perl conference is nearly upon us, so we have several related posts.
If you're going, get the app from Infinity Interactive on your phone!
If you want to see a book on web application development in Perl 6, you could support Gabor's crowdfunding campaign.
subject: The Perl Conference is nearly upon us
